results.title: Werner Herzog eats his shoe
results.brief_description:
In 1979 German film director Werner Herzog publicly ate his desert boots to honour a wager that he had made to Errol Morris, after Morris succeeded in completing one of the films he always talked about. Includes footage from ‘Even Dwarfs Started Small’ and ‘The Gold Rush’.
Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Werckmeister harmonies. Damnation = Werckmeister harmoniak. Karhozat
results.creator_credit: Bela Tarr, Josef Marx, Paul Saadoun, Joachim von Vietinghoff, Miklos Szita, Franz Goess, Magyar Televizio, Mokep, Magyar Filmintezet, 13 Productions, Von Vietinghoff Filmproduktion and Goess Films
results.brief_description: Werckmeister harmonies: Haunting and atmospheric, this slow-moving narrative filmed in stark black and white reflects the harsh political environment that is Eastern Europe. The main character, Jancos (Lars Rudolph), a visionary and an outsider is drawn to the arrival in his bleak provincial town on the Hungarian plains, of a circus featuring the stuffed carcass of a massive dead whale and a mysterious, somewhat sinister figure called “The Prince”. What follows this arrival into this already economically depressed village is quite disturbing. Using long and lingering shots, the images create nuances and subtleties that make “Werckmeister harmonies” an intriguing and beautiful film. Cast also includes Peter Fitz, Hanna Schygulla. Based on “The Melancholy of Resistance” by Laszlo Krasznahorkai. “Damnation”: Featuring Bela Tarr’s renowned long takes and bleak black and white images, this story follows Karrer (Miklos B. Szekely), a sullen and listless man obsessed with a married woman (Vali Kerekes) who sings at a local bar, the Titanik. Betrayal and conflict eventually lead to despair for Karrer and alienation from those around him. Extremely slow, beautifully photographed and quite depressing but definitely compelling. Cast also includes Gyula Pauer, Gyorgy Cserhalmi. A collaboration with writer Laszlo Krasznahorkai.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bela Tarr, Josef Marx, Paul Saadoun, Joachim von Vietinghoff, Miklos Szita, Franz Goess, Magyar Televizio, Mokep, Magyar Filmintezet, 13 Productions, Von Vietinghoff Filmproduktion and Goess Films

results.title: Wendy cracked a walnut
results.creator_credit: Michael Pattinson, John Edwards, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Classic Films
results.brief_description: Wendy Walters yearns for the passion she finds between the pages of romance novels. Her life is not bad, just boring. When husband Ronnie forgets their wedding anniversary, Wendy stumbles into an affair with the rich and handsome Jake. All fairy tales must come to an end and even though Wendy discovers that Jake is not Prince Charming, hers still has a happy ending.

results.title: Well, what are you doing now?
results.brief_description: This is a unique video made by a group of older Australians which promotes positive images of older adults in a range of community recreation activities. The group have demonstrated their capacity to master technical audio visual equipment and produce a challenging VHS video.

results.title: Welfare of the workers
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Jennings, Great Britain. Ministry of Information and GPO Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows efforts by the British government to maintain production during the war. Many working men and women were required to relocate to factories away from their home town to support the changing production demands of war. Recognising that the health, safety and welfare of workers was critical to victory, various programs were implemented to assist relocated workers. These varied from locating suitable accommodation, providing health services and ensuring that recreational activities were available to workers during their leisure time. New lighting and ventilation designs were also introduced into factories to compensate for the conditions caused by the blackouts that were enforced during aerial attacks.

results.title: Welfare [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Frederick Wiseman, Zipporah Films and Welfare Films
results.brief_description: The Waverley Welfare Center in Manhattan has to cope with an expanding population and shrinking resources. More than any other Wiseman film, Welfare is about an institution under pressure as it is required to take on more and more functions. The bureaucratic response tends to be to classify (with an attendant vocabulary) rather than tackle the basic problem of just distribution in what amounts to a cycle of deprivation, in which ‘clients must repeatedly present themselves as devoid of all economic support and moral strength in order to qualify for financial help and that may never be adequate in such a situation’.

results.title: Welcoming valley: the mighty Murray
results.brief_description: Victorian Government promotional film extolling the virtues of the Murray River Valley as a tourist destination. Includes footage of Yarrawonga/Mulwala, Echuca, Cohuna, Kerang, Swan Hill and Mildura.
